comments.comment:
I have a quick fix for this committed (545553) but I'm confused by the behaviour of the AutoloadedDriver.

When Derby is shutdown the autoloaded driver does not remove itself from the driver manager, even though it seems it will not honour any connection request until the embedded driver is explicitly loaded. What is the purpose of keeping Derby code running once the application has explicitly asked for it to be removed?

Another minor issue is that the javadoc for the class is incorrect, it is not only used in JDBC 4/JDK 6, it seems to be an integral part of the embedded driver boot process.

Now that the errors described in the title for this bug have been 'quick-fixed', do the things Dan mentions need to be fixed in 10.3? Can the title be changed or a new bug logged to track those issues?

Dan asked:

>When Derby is shutdown the autoloaded driver does not remove itself from the driver manager, even though it seems it will not honour any connection request until the embedded driver is explicitly loaded. >What is the purpose of keeping Derby code running once the application has explicitly asked for it to be removed?

I don't know what, if anything, would break if the AutoloadedDriver unregistered itself. The embedded driver reference should be nulled out if the engine is shut down. Is that not happening? What Derby code do you see running?

> Another minor issue is that the javadoc for the class is incorrect, it is not only used in JDBC 4/JDK 6, it seems to be an integral part of the embedded driver boot process.

You are right. The AutoloadedDriver is loaded regardless of your JDBC level. The javadoc should be corrected.

Removing 10.3 fix-in...The original problem was resolved.
Rick, you did you intend to look at changing the javadoc?
Attacing derby-2788-javadoc-01.diff. This clarifies the javadoc header in AutoloadedDriver. This also cleans up some javadoc warnings in TypeDescriptorImpl. Committed at subversion revision 546866.

By code running I meant the autoload driver is still registered in DriverManager. This reference will keep the ClassLoader that loaded Derby in the system forever, even if al other references to it have gone away. This in turn means all the code loaded by that ClassLoader (including all of Derby) will remain live.
Issue is fixed. I will enter another bug for the fact that shutting down Derby does not remove all Derby code from a system
